thread.title_full: VMworld conference: Some fancy footwork afoot for VMware | The Australian

author: The Australian
title: VMworld conference: Some fancy footwork afoot for VMware |
text:
It is somewhat fitting, given the real elephant in the Moscone Centre’s North Hall, where Mr Gelsinger was speaking, was the question of VMware’s future as part of the ‘federation’ of EMC companies.
VMware, along with software development platform Pivotal and security firm RSA, is one of the companies controlled by enterprise storage giant EMC, which activist shareholders believe would be better standing alone, a view compounded by the relative value of the two biggest companies.
EMC, with 80 per cent of the publicly listed VMware, has a market capitalisation of $US46 billion ($66bn) compared to the smaller company at $US34bn. The fact that VMware is growing — 10 per cent last year compared to its parent’s anaemic 2 per cent — has emboldened the activists.
VMware management believes the share price is a short-term issue: “Clearly, the issue at the highest level is EMC as an entity has outperformed the industry in growth rates and such and underperformed in the stock price, it’s that simple,” Mr Gelsinger told The Australian .
“The question for the board is how to get better share price performance. Shareholder activists are pretty simple folk.
“Their common denominator is stock price, their objective is to as quickly as possible drive change that increases shareholder value. We’ve laid out our strategies with both businesses on what we think will work and I believe in the long term we’ll be rewarded for that.”
Part of the plan is to broaden its product range, from endpoint device security, following its Airwatch acquisition last year, to software-defined data centres to power the next generation of in-house computing services.
The key shift remains the cloud. “Every company has this challenge ahead of them and we’re not any different.”
VMware’s key strategy is to push its Unified Hybrid Cloud offering of technologies that connect enterprise networks with private and public cloud offerings, such as the VCloud Air service it launched in Australia last year with Telstra as its highest-profile partner.
Duncan Bennet, VMware’s Australia and New Zealand manager, doesn’t see the cloud service’s tie up with Telstra as a handbrake to adoption in the Australian market. “It’s not an exclusive relationship, it’s a location for the data centre.”
Mr Bennet sees bridging the gap between on-premise and cloud data centres, along with management of mobile devices, as the key opportunities for VMware in Australia.
The Unified Hybrid Cloud was the main theme of the company’s announcements at the annual conference, where VMWare showcased the range of products intended to grow its customer base. A Microsoft cameo is becoming a regular thing at Bay Area tech events these days and, true to form, the two announced a joint product to manage Windows 10 devices.
“There’s nothing new about ‘co-opetition’,” Mr Gelsinger said. “There are plenty of areas we’re going to compete with Microsoft, hyper-V versus VSphere, we’re going to fight to the death.”
In a shifting marketplace and with activist shareholders on EMC’s tail, VMWare’s management faces a substantial task in training its virtualised elephant to dance.
